results.title: Taliban Announce Some Government Posts, and Protests Pose a Challenge
results.abstract: The Taliban’s violent response to the latest demonstration, which included hundreds of women in Kabul, was another sign that they will not tolerate peaceful dissent in Afghanistan.
results.byline: By Jim Huylebroek and Matthieu Aikins

multimedia.caption: Women and men fleeing the scene of a protest after Taliban forces broke it up in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Tuesday.

results.title: Charter Flights Delayed as U.S. and Taliban Struggle to Work Together
results.abstract: With the Kabul airport closed, scores of people have tried to leave via  the airport in the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif. But the U.S. and the Taliban have struggled to establish an efficient system.
results.byline: By Michael Crowley, Wali Arian and Sami Sahak

multimedia.caption: Commercial planes sitting near the main terminal of the Mazar-i-Sharif airport, Afghanistan, on Friday.
Commercial planes sitting near the main terminal of the Mazar-i-Sharif airport, Afghanistan, on Friday.

results.title: From Afghanistan to the World Cup, Tiny, Wealthy Qatar Steps Up
results.abstract: The Gulf state played a major role in the American airlift, the latest evidence of the small but gas-rich country punching above its weight on the world stage.

multimedia.caption: A Qatari flight taking off from the Kabul airport last week. Since the Taliban takeover, Qatar has sent tons of aid to Kabul and worked to re-open the airport.

results.title: Pro-Bolsonaro Rallies May Be Prelude to Power Grab, Critics Say
results.abstract: Critics see in the rhetoric of the leader, who is seeing declining poll numbers and mounting legal challenges, a parallel to former President Donald J. Trump’s.
results.byline: By Flávia Milhorance and Ernesto Londoño

results.title: A Vaccine Success in Europe That Sinks in the East
results.abstract: Partly because of skepticism about shots, Bulgaria has fully inoculated only 20 percent of adults, and Romania 32 percent, well below the European Union average of 70 percent.
results.byline: By Elian Peltier, Boryana Dzhambazova and Monika Pronczuk

multimedia.caption: A medical worker behind a plastic panel inside a mobile vaccination unit in Bucharest, Romania, on Saturday. Vaccine uptake has slowed down significantly in the country.

results.title: She’s Green. She’s Young. And She Wants to Change Germany.
results.abstract: Annalena Baerbock, the 40-year-old candidate for the Green Party, is likely to have a say in Germany’s next government, no matter who wins this month’s election.

multimedia.caption: Annalena Baerbock, the Green Party candidate for chancellor, addressing a crowd at the mining museum in Bochum, Germany.

results.title: Warning of Income Gap, Xi Tells China’s Tycoons to Share Wealth
results.abstract: As the country’s leader prepares for a likely third term, he is promising “common prosperity” to lift farmers and working families into the middle class.
results.byline: By Chris Buckley, Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

multimedia.caption: Xi Jinping has declared that China’s Communist Party will work toward “common prosperity,” and he has pressed businesses and entrepreneurs to give back more to society.

results.title: Glitches mar El Salvador’s adoption of Bitcoin as an official currency.
results.abstract: Experts raised concerns in June about the hasty adoption of the new currency and the rapid execution of new technology on a national scale.
results.byline: By Ephrat Livni and Oscar Lopez

results.title: Alibaba Manager Accused of Rape Is Released, Adding to China’s #MeToo Debate
results.abstract: Prosecutors declined to charge the man, who a co-worker said had assaulted her, an allegation that highlighted sexism in the Chinese tech scene.

multimedia.caption: Alibaba’s office in Beijing. The e-commerce giant, with headquarters in Hangzhou, China, has been at the center of a discussion about sexism in the country’s technology scene.

results.title: To Avoid River Flooding, Go With the Flow, the Dutch Say
results.abstract: Extreme rainfall is causing deadly and destructive floods globally. The Netherlands averted disaster this summer by creating flood plains.

multimedia.caption: A farmland scene in the Netherlands, a country that has faced sea-level rise and river floods long before climate change became a worry.

results.title: Mexico City to Replace Columbus Statue With Indigenous Woman Monument
results.abstract: “We owe it to them. We exist because of them,” the mayor of Mexico City said in a news conference.

results.title: With Her Party Fading, Merkel Dips Into the Campaign Fray
results.abstract: Germany’s chancellor pleaded with voters to support her party, which has flagging poll numbers and a candidate who has failed to capture imaginations.

results.title: Manhunt Underway After 6 Palestinians Escape Israeli Prison
results.abstract: Four of the fugitives had been convicted of terror offenses and were serving at least two life sentences, while legal proceedings continued for the other two.

results.title: As Migrants Surge Toward Border, Court Hands Biden a Lifeline
results.abstract: Desperate to control the unrelenting buildup on the border, Biden administration officials turn their focus to deterring migration, dashing hopes of asylum seekers.
results.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe

multimedia.caption: Migrants, mostly from Central America and Haiti, waiting on the International Bridge last month in Matamoros, Mexico, to enter the United States to request asylum.
